e4: Switching to the unbiased policy aligns with ethical standards and transparency, reducing potential legal liabilities and cultivating trust with investors. Though there may be initial investor misunderstandings, it favors long-term credibility and aligns reported earnings with reality, helping retail and unsophisticated investors better understand the company's true performance.
e5: An ethical reporting policy should prioritize transparency and honesty, accurately reflecting the company’s performance without deliberate bias or omissions. It should maintain consistency while considering impacts on all investor types, including retail and unsophisticated ones. Legal compliance, fairness to all stakeholders, and long-term trust over short-term gains are paramount.
e6: What strategies does management propose to effectively communicate policy changes to the investor community? How do they plan to mitigate short-term impacts on retail investors? Moreover, are there historical instances of policy changes closer to industry standards done seamlessly elsewhere that our investor relations can benchmark against?
